9.passage:
American candy s the best candy."

"And are American little boys the best little boys?" asked [MASK].

"I don t know.

11.passage:
I m an American boy," said the child.

"I see you are one of the best!" laughed [MASK].

"Are you an American man?" pursued this vivacious infant.

17.passage:
American girls are the best girls," he said cheerfully to his young companion.

"My sister ain t the best!" [MASK] declared.

19.passage:
She s always blowing at me."

"I imagine that is your fault, not hers," said [MASK]. The young lady meanwhile had drawn near.

20.passage:
She was bareheaded, but she balanced in her hand a large parasol, with a deep border of embroidery; and she was strikingly, admirably pretty. "How pretty they are!" thought [MASK], straightening himself in his seat, as if he were prepared to rise.

The young lady paused in front of his bench, near the parapet of the garden, which overlooked the lake.

28.passage: He got up and stepped slowly toward the young girl, throwing away his cigarette. "This little boy and I have made acquaintance," [MASK] said, with great civility. In Geneva, as he had been perfectly aware, a young man was not at liberty to speak to a young unmarried lady except under certain rarely occurring conditions; but here at Vevey, what conditions could be better than these?--a pretty American girl coming and standing in front of you in a garden.

34.passage:
Well, I guess you had better leave it somewhere," she said after a moment.

"Are you going to Italy?" [MASK] inquired in a tone of great respect.

35.passage: The young lady glanced at him again. "Yes, sir," [MASK] replied. And she said nothing more.

36.passage:
And she said nothing more.

"Are you--a--going over the Simplon?" [MASK] pursued, a little embarrassed.

42.passage:
I don t know," said [MASK]. "I don t want to go to Italy. I want to go to America."

"Oh, Italy is a beautiful place!" rejoined the young man.

44.passage:
Oh, Italy is a beautiful place!" rejoined the young man.

"Can you get candy there?" [MASK] loudly inquired.

65.passage:
He doesn t like Europe," said [MASK]. "He wants to go back."

"To Schenectady, you mean?"

"Yes; he wants to go right home.

68.passage:
There is one boy here, but he always goes round with a teacher; they won t let him play."

"And your brother hasn t any teacher?" [MASK] inquired.

73.passage:
Can you get good teachers in Italy?"

"Very good, I should think," said [MASK].

"Or else she s going to find some school.

81.passage: In New York I had lots of society. Last winter I had seventeen dinners given me; and three of them were by gentlemen," added [MASK]. "I have more friends in New York than in Schenectady--more gentleman friends; and more young lady friends too," she resumed in a moment.

87.passage:
Yes, formerly, more than once," said [MASK]. "You too, I suppose, have seen it?"

"No; we haven t been there.

105.passage:
But did you really mean what you said just now--that you would like to go up there?"

"Most earnestly," [MASK] declared.

"Then we may arrange it.

112.passage:
[MASK] said; "I m going to that old castle, anyway."

"To the Chateau de Chillon, mademoiselle?" the courier inquired.

116.passage:
she said.

"I shall not be happy till we go!" [MASK] protested.

120.passage:
I shall have the honor of presenting to you a person who will tell you all about me,"  he said, smiling and referring to his aunt.

"Oh, well, we ll go some day," said [MASK]. And she gave him a smile and turned away.

121.passage:
As soon as the former lady had got better of her headache, he waited upon her in her apartment; and, after the proper inquiries in regard to her health, he asked her if she had observed in the hotel an American family--a mamma, a daughter, and a little boy.

"And a courier?" said [MASK]. "Oh yes, I have observed them.

130.passage:
But she is very common."

"I see what you mean, of course," said [MASK] after another pause.

"She has that charming look that they all have," his aunt resumed.

134.passage:
But, my dear aunt, she is not, after all, a Comanche savage."

"She is a young lady," said [MASK], "who has an intimacy with her mamma s courier."

"An intimacy with the courier?" the young man demanded.

156.passage:
Dear me!" cried [MASK]. "What a dreadful girl!"

Her nephew was silent for some moments.

157.passage: Her nephew was silent for some moments. "You really think, then," [MASK] began earnestly, and with a desire for trustworthy information--"you really think that--" But he paused again.

169.passage:
I am an old woman, but I am not too old, thank Heaven, to be shocked!"

"But don t they all do these things--the young girls in America?"  [MASK] inquired.

174.passage:
Has she gone to bed?"

"No; she doesn t like to go to bed," said [MASK]. "She doesn t sleep--not three hours.

181.passage: Every two days she had a headache. "I think that s a lovely description, headache and all!" said [MASK], chattering along in her thin, gay voice. "I want to know her ever so much.

187.passage: Her prettiness was still visible in the darkness; she was opening and closing her enormous fan. "She doesn t want to know me!" [MASK] said suddenly.

192.passage: You needn t be afraid," [MASK] repeated. "Why should she want to know me?" Then she paused again; she was close to the parapet of the garden, and in front of her was the starlit lake.

195.passage:
Suddenly it seemed to pause.

"Are you sure it is your mother? Can you distinguish her in this thick dusk?" [MASK] asked.

216.passage:
I don t know," said her mother, turning toward the lake again.

"I shouldn t think you d want that shawl!" [MASK] exclaimed.

246.passage:
I have never been to that castle."

"It is a pity you shouldn t go," said [MASK], beginning to feel reassured as to her opposition. And yet he was quite prepared to find that, as a matter of course, she meant to accompany her daughter.

254.passage:
It seems as if there was nothing she wouldn t undertake."

"Oh, I think she ll enjoy it!" [MASK] declared.

270.passage:
I will row you over to Chillon in the starlight."

"I don t believe it!" said [MASK].

"Well!" ejaculated the elder lady again.

282.passage:
But I am afraid you are chaffing me."

"I think not, sir," remarked [MASK] very gently.

"Do, then, let me give you a row," he said to the young girl.

286.passage:
It will be still more lovely to do it."

"Yes, it would be lovely!" said [MASK]. But she made no movement to accompany him; she only stood there laughing.

313.passage:
[MASK] asked. "I had an idea I was grinning from ear to ear."

"You look as if you were taking me to a funeral.

323.passage: I don t believe it!" said [MASK]. "What do you mean? You are not in business." The young man admitted that he was not in business; but he had engagements which, even within a day or two, would force him to go back to Geneva.

325.passage: Oh, bother!" [MASK] said; "I don t believe it!" and she began to talk about something else.

349.passage:
Men are welcome to the privilege!"

"Pray what is it that happens--here, for instance?" [MASK] demanded.

366.passage:
I arrived only yesterday."

"I don t believe that!" [MASK] declared.

375.passage:
Not very well, sir," she answered.

"She s got the dyspepsia," said [MASK]. "I ve got it too.

399.passage:
He remembered that a cynical compatriot had once told him that American women--the pretty ones, and this gave a largeness to the axiom--were at once the most exacting in the world and the least endowed with a sense of indebtedness.

"Why, you were awfully mean at Vevey," said [MASK]. "You wouldn t do anything.

449.passage:
I have had the honor of telling you that I have only just stepped out of the train."

"You must have stayed in the train a good while after it stopped!" cried [MASK] with her little laugh. "I suppose you were asleep.

460.passage:
He had a handsome face, an artfully poised hat, a glass in one eye, and a nosegay in his buttonhole. [MASK] looked at him a moment and then said, "Do you mean to speak to that man?"

"Do I mean to speak to him?

466.passage:
I don t like the way you say that," said [MASK]. "It s too imperious."

"I beg your pardon if I say it wrong.

477.passage: It was true that, if he was an imitation, the imitation was brilliant. "Nevertheless," [MASK] said to himself, "a nice girl ought to know!" And then he came back to the question whether this was, in fact, a nice girl.

497.passage:
Well, it ought to be, then!" said [MASK]. "If I didn t walk I should expire."

"You should walk with your mother, dear," cried the lady from Geneva, losing patience.

498.passage:
If I didn t walk I should expire."

"You should walk with your mother, dear," cried [MASK], losing patience.

"With my mother dear!" exclaimed the young girl.

501.passage:
My mother never walked ten steps in her life. And then, you know," [MASK] added with a laugh, "I am more than five years old."

"You are old enough to be more reasonable.

525.passage:
Her mother goes away when visitors come."

"But her brother," said [MASK], laughing, "sits up till midnight."

"He must be edified by what he sees.

531.passage:
The poor girl s only fault," he presently added, "is that she is very uncultivated."

"She is naturally indelicate," [MASK] declared.

"Take that example this morning.

541.passage:
There shall be nothing scandalous in my attentions to her."

"There certainly will be in the way she takes them. But I have said what I had on my conscience," [MASK] pursued. "If you wish to rejoin the young lady I will put you down.

568.passage:
The young ladies of this country have a dreadfully poky time of it, so far as I can learn; I don t see why I should change my habits for THEM."

"I am afraid your habits are those of a flirt," said [MASK] gravely.

"Of course they are," she cried, giving him her little smiling stare again.

571.passage:
But I suppose you will tell me now that I am not a nice girl."

"You re a very nice girl; but I wish you would flirt with me, and me only," said [MASK].

"Ah! thank you--thank you very much; you are the last man I should think of flirting with.

612.passage:
It was the courier probably who introduced him; and if he succeeds in marrying the young lady, the courier will come in for a magnificent commission."

"I don t believe she thinks of marrying him," said [MASK], "and I don t believe he hopes to marry her."

"You may be very sure she thinks of nothing.

645.passage:
[MASK] exclaimed seriously. "But I don t believe it. They are only pretending to be shocked. They don t really care a straw what I do. Besides, I don t go round so much."

"I think you will find they do care.

658.passage:
she said.

"How can I help it?" [MASK] asked.

669.passage:
He was silent a moment; and then, "Yes, I believe it," he said.

"Oh, no, you don t!" [MASK] answered.

675.passage: that was no reason for her dying of the perniciosa. "How long have you been here?" [MASK] asked almost brutally.

678.passage:
* * "I never saw anything so pretty."

"I am afraid," said [MASK], "that you will not think Roman fever very pretty. This is the way people catch it.

686.passage:
I told the signorina it was a grave indiscretion, but when was the signorina ever prudent?"

"I never was sick, and I don t mean to be!" [MASK] declared.

691.passage: What you say is very wise," [MASK] rejoined. "I will go and make sure the carriage is at hand." And he went forward rapidly.

715.passage:
He looked on the ground a moment, and then he said, "For myself I had no fear; and she wanted to go."

"That was no reason!" [MASK] declared.

720.passage:
I am sure I don t know," said [MASK]. "How did your injustice affect her?"

"She sent me a message before her death which I didn t understand at the time; but I have understood it since.
